intro: Neanotis thwaitesiana, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a member of the Asparagaceae family. It is a perennial herbaceous plant native to New Zealand, characterized by its long, narrow leaves that are often used for weaving traditional Māori garments. The plant typically grows in wet, swampy areas and has a fibrous, woody stem that becomes more prominent with age. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, clustered in panicles, and it plays an important ecological role in its native habitat.
